elements.content: Three isomorphic decanuclear heterometallic 3d–4f Ln2Cu8 clusters, formulated as [Ln2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]·15H2O (Ln = La (1, La2Cu8); Ln = Gd (2, Gd 2 Cu8); Ln = Dy (3, Dy 2 Cu 8 ), H5TMHSA = 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]-2-hydroxyprop-anesulfonic acid), were obtained through the reaction of H5TMHSA, Ln(ClO4)3, and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. The present three Ln2Cu8 compounds are rare examples of alkylsulfonate-based polynuclear 3d–4f clusters. Magnetic studies indicate that the cluster La2Cu8 exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior, Gd2Cu8 displays ferromagnetic behavior and a large magnetocaloric effect at low temperature, while Dy2Cu8 shows slow magnetic relaxation.
elements.clean_text: Three isomorphic decanuclear heterometallic 3d-4f Ln2Cu8 clusters, formulated as [Ln2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]⋅15H2O (Ln = La (1, La2Cu8); Ln = Gd (2, Gd 2 Cu8); Ln = Dy (3, Dy 2 Cu 8 ), H5TMHSA = 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]-2-hydroxyprop-anesulfonic acid), were obtained through the reaction of H5TMHSA, Ln(ClO4)3, and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. The present three Ln2Cu8 compounds are rare examples of alkylsulfonate-based polynuclear 3d-4f clusters. Magnetic studies indicate that the cluster La2Cu8 exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior, Gd2Cu8 displays ferromagnetic behavior and a large magnetocaloric effect at low temperature, while Dy2Cu8 shows slow magnetic relaxation.

elements.content: Three isostructural decanuclear 3d−4f Ln2Cu8 clusters were obtained. Magnetic studies indicate that the cluster La2Cu8 exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior, Gd2Cu8 displays ferromagnetic behavior and a large magnetocaloric effect at low temperature, while Dy2Cu8 shows slow magnetic relaxation.
elements.clean_text: Three isostructural decanuclear 3d-4f Ln2Cu8 clusters were obtained. Magnetic studies indicate that the cluster La2Cu8 exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior, Gd2Cu8 displays ferromagnetic behavior and a large magnetocaloric effect at low temperature, while Dy2Cu8 shows slow magnetic relaxation.

elements.content: In the past decade, the design and synthesis of heterometallic 3d–4f polynuclear clusters have received intense interest because of their intriguing architectures, their interesting properties, and potential applications. More recently, the study of attractive magnetic properties of 3d–4f molecule-based materials is a most notable topic, because of the unique exchange interactions between their metal ions. For example, many anisotropic Dy3+-based 3d–Dy clusters have been demonstrated to exhibit single-molecule magnetism, while some of isotropic Gd3+-based heterometallic 3d–Gd clusters have been displayed to show a large magnetocaloric effect. However, owing to the synthetic difficulty in simultaneously satisfying the distinctly different coordination requirements of 3d metal and 4f elements, the design of heterometallic 3d–4f clusters with desired structures still remains a great challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, the design and synthesis of heterometallic 3d-4f polynuclear clusters have received intense interest because of their intriguing architectures, their interesting properties, and potential applications. More recently, the study of attractive magnetic properties of 3d-4f molecule-based materials is a most notable topic, because of the unique exchange interactions between their metal ions. For example, many anisotropic Dy3+-based 3d-Dy clusters have been demonstrated to exhibit single-molecule magnetism, while some of isotropic Gd3+-based heterometallic 3d-Gd clusters have been displayed to show a large magnetocaloric effect. However, owing to the synthetic difficulty in simultaneously satisfying the distinctly different coordination requirements of 3d metal and 4f elements, the design of heterometallic 3d-4f clusters with desired structures still remains a great challenge.

elements.content: The multifunctional ligand containing different electron donating groups, such as −NH, −OH, −COOH, −SO3, and −PO3, are logical candidates to connect transition metal and lanthanide ions, because different groups favor coordination with different metals. Here, the 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]-2-hydroxyprop-anesulfonic acid (Scheme , H5TMHSA), possessing four hydroxy, one imine, and one alkylsulfonate group, was selected as the multifunctional bridging ligand to construct 3d–4f clusters. First, the H5TMHSA ligand contains three hydroxymethyl groups, which have shown their versatile coordination mode with transition metal and lanthanide ions. Second, the imine group is an effective group bonded to 3d metal ions. Third, the alkylsulfonate group R-SO3 – in the ligand can adopt a variety of coordination modes. Finally, additional functional hydroxyl groups may improve the coordination of sulfonate ligand. By means of structural retrieval, it is found that the ligand has never been used to synthetize coordination compounds. In this work, based on H5TMHSA, three decanuclear Ln2Cu8 clusters, formulated as [Ln2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2­(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]­·15H2O (Ln = La (1); Ln = Gd (2); Ln = Dy (3)), were obtained through the reaction of H5TMHSA, Ln(ClO4)3, and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Notably, the Ln2Cu8 clusters are rare examples of alkylsulfonate-based polynuclear 3d-4f clusters.
elements.clean_text: The multifunctional ligand containing different electron donating groups, such as -NH, -OH, -COOH, -SO3, and -PO3, are logical candidates to connect transition metal and lanthanide ions, because different groups favor coordination with different metals. Here, the 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]-2-hydroxyprop-anesulfonic acid (Scheme , H5TMHSA), possessing four hydroxy, one imine, and one alkylsulfonate group, was selected as the multifunctional bridging ligand to construct 3d-4f clusters. First, the H5TMHSA ligand contains three hydroxymethyl groups, which have shown their versatile coordination mode with transition metal and lanthanide ions. Second, the imine group is an effective group bonded to 3d metal ions. Third, the alkylsulfonate group R-SO3 - in the ligand can adopt a variety of coordination modes. Finally, additional functional hydroxyl groups may improve the coordination of sulfonate ligand. By means of structural retrieval, it is found that the ligand has never been used to synthetize coordination compounds. In this work, based on H5TMHSA, three decanuclear Ln2Cu8 clusters, formulated as [Ln2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]⋅15H2O (Ln = La (1); Ln = Gd (2); Ln = Dy (3)), were obtained through the reaction of H5TMHSA, Ln(ClO4)3, and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. Notably, the Ln2Cu8 clusters are rare examples of alkylsulfonate-based polynuclear 3d-4f clusters.

elements.clean_text: 1  The H5TMHSA Ligand

elements.content: All reagents were of commercial origin and were used as received. The ligand H5TMHSA was obtained from the company TCI and its minimum purity is 98%. Aqueous solutions of lanthanide perchlorates were prepared by digesting lanthanide oxides in concentrated perchloric. A suitable concentration was achieved by dilution of the concentrated solution with deionized water. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. The infrared spectrum was recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. TGA curves were prepared on a SDT Q600 thermal analyzer. Magnetic susceptibility was measured by a Quantum Design MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All reagents were of commercial origin and were used as received. The ligand H5TMHSA was obtained from the company TCI and its minimum purity is 98%. Aqueous solutions of lanthanide perchlorates were prepared by digesting lanthanide oxides in concentrated perchloric. A suitable concentration was achieved by dilution of the concentrated solution with deionized water. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. The infrared spectrum was recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. TGA curves were prepared on a SDT Q600 thermal analyzer. Magnetic susceptibility was measured by a Quantum Design MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID).

elements.content: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242g, 1.0 mmol), La(ClO4)3 (2 mL, aq. 1.0 M), and 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)-methylamino]-2-hydroxypropanesulfonic acid (0.130g, 0.5 mmol) were added to deionized water (10 mL). The resulting solution was heated to reflux, and its pH was adjusted to about 7 with the addition of NaOH (aq. 1.0 M). The mixture was refluxed for 1 h and then filtrated. Evaporation of the deep blue solution under ambient conditions afforded 110 mg of blue crystals 1 over one month (yield 34.3% based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8La2N4O65S4 (%) Anal. (FW = 2524.474): C, 13.32%; H, 4.23%; N, 2.22%; Found: C, 13.77%; H, 4.47%; N, 2.20%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[La2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]⋅15H2O (1)

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.242g, 1.0 mmol), La(ClO4)3 (2 mL, aq. 1.0 M), and 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)-methylamino]-2-hydroxypropanesulfonic acid (0.130g, 0.5 mmol) were added to deionized water (10 mL). The resulting solution was heated to reflux, and its pH was adjusted to about 7 with the addition of NaOH (aq. 1.0 M). The mixture was refluxed for 1 h and then filtrated. Evaporation of the deep blue solution under ambient conditions afforded 110 mg of blue crystals 1 over one month (yield 34.3% based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8La2N4O65S4 (%) Anal. (FW = 2524.474): C, 13.32%; H, 4.23%; N, 2.22%; Found: C, 13.77%; H, 4.47%; N, 2.20%.

elements.content: This compound was prepared using Gd(ClO4)3 in place of La(ClO4)3 under otherwise identical conditions as described above which afforded 132 mg of blue sheetlike crystals of 2 (Yield: 40.0%, based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8Gd2N4O65S4 Anal. (FW = 2561.163): C, 13.13%; H, 4.17%; N, 2.19%; Found: C, 13.16%; H, 4.33%; N, 2.12%.

elements.content: Data of compound 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 nm) at 273 K. Data of compounds 2 and 3 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER IP CCD area detector with monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 173K. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated geometrically (C–H, 0.96 Å). CCDC contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper with a deposition number of CCDC 857677– 857679 for 1–3, respectively. The crystallographic data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystal data, as well as details of the data collection and refinement, for 1–3 are summarized in Table . The selected bonds and angles for 1–3 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Determination

Data of compound 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 nm) at 273 K. Data of compounds 2 and 3 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER IP CCD area detector with monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 173K. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated geometrically (C-H, 0.96 Å). CCDC contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper with a deposition number of CCDC 857677- 857679 for 1-3, respectively. The crystallographic data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystal data, as well as details of the data collection and refinement, for 1-3 are summarized in Table . The selected bonds and angles for 1-3 are summarized in .

The construction of polynuclear 3d–4f compounds is currently of interest. The metalloligand strategy has been studied most extensively to construct polynuclear 3d–4f clusters. In addition, some carboxylate, phosphonate, N,O-chelating, and bridging ligands also have been investigated. Although alkylsulfonate groups R-SO3 – can adopt a variety of coordination modes, reports on the coordination chemistry of alkylsulfonate ligands with lanthanide, especially lanthanide-transition metals, are still very rare. Here, based on 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]-2-hydroxyprop-anesulfonic acid, three decanuclear Ln2Cu8 clusters were obtained through the reaction of H5TMHSA, Ln(ClO4)3, and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Structure analysis shows that the meta-hydroxyl groups may improve the coordination of the sulfonate ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Compounds 1-3 

The construction of polynuclear 3d-4f compounds is currently of interest. The metalloligand strategy has been studied most extensively to construct polynuclear 3d-4f clusters. In addition, some carboxylate, phosphonate, N,O-chelating, and bridging ligands also have been investigated. Although alkylsulfonate groups R-SO3 - can adopt a variety of coordination modes, reports on the coordination chemistry of alkylsulfonate ligands with lanthanide, especially lanthanide-transition metals, are still very rare. Here, based on 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]-2-hydroxyprop-anesulfonic acid, three decanuclear Ln2Cu8 clusters were obtained through the reaction of H5TMHSA, Ln(ClO4)3, and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. Structure analysis shows that the meta-hydroxyl groups may improve the coordination of the sulfonate ligand.

elements.content: Crystal structural analysis reveals that compounds 1–3 are isostructural. Thus, only the structure of 1 is discussed below to illustrate the common salient structural features. Compound 1 crystallizes in the P21/c space group. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 1 is made of two [HTMHSA]4– ligands, one La3+ and four Cu2+ ions, one μ2-OH– and one μ3-OH– anion, one ClO4 – anion, and five aqua ligands. The La3+ ion locates in the center of a dicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry and is octa-coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, in which four oxygens come from two ligands, one oxygen comes from μ3-OH and three aqua ligands (Figure b). All the Cu2+ ions in the cluster are pentacoordinated in quadrilateral pyramidal coordination geometry. Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and La1 ions are linked by four hydroxyl groups from two ligands and one μ3-OH–, forming a tetranuclear LaCu3 square. Cu4 and Cu4A are connected by two μ2-OH–, generating a dinuclear Cu2 unit. The metal cluster core can be viewed as a connection of two tetranuclear LaCu3 squares and one dinuclear Cu2 unit (Figure ). As shown in Figure c, the HTMHSA4– ligand displays a μ4:η1:η2:η1:η2:η2 coordination fashion, in which one N and four O atoms coordinate with three Cu(II) ions and one La(III) ion. The La–O distances range from 2.394(4) to 2.844(10) Å. Cu–O distances are in the range of 1.901(4)–2.415(4) Å, which are comparable to those in reported compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Crystal structural analysis reveals that compounds 1-3 are isostructural. Thus, only the structure of 1 is discussed below to illustrate the common salient structural features. Compound 1 crystallizes in the P21/c space group. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of 1 is made of two [HTMHSA]4- ligands, one La3+ and four Cu2+ ions, one μ2-OH- and one μ3-OH- anion, one ClO4 - anion, and five aqua ligands. The La3+ ion locates in the center of a dicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry and is octa-coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, in which four oxygens come from two ligands, one oxygen comes from μ3-OH and three aqua ligands (Figure b). All the Cu2+ ions in the cluster are pentacoordinated in quadrilateral pyramidal coordination geometry. Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and La1 ions are linked by four hydroxyl groups from two ligands and one μ3-OH-, forming a tetranuclear LaCu3 square. Cu4 and Cu4A are connected by two μ2-OH-, generating a dinuclear Cu2 unit. The metal cluster core can be viewed as a connection of two tetranuclear LaCu3 squares and one dinuclear Cu2 unit (Figure ). As shown in Figure c, the HTMHSA4- ligand displays a μ4:η1:η2:η1:η2:η2 coordination fashion, in which one N and four O atoms coordinate with three Cu(II) ions and one La(III) ion. The La-O distances range from 2.394(4) to 2.844(10) Å. Cu-O distances are in the range of 1.901(4)-2.415(4) Å, which are comparable to those in reported compounds.

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural to 1. As shown in , for 2, the Gd–O and Cu–O bond lengths are in range of 2.294(4)–2.555(4) Å and 1.921(4)–2.338(6) Å. For 3, the Dy–O and Cu–O bond lengths are in range of 2.281(5)–2.547(5) Å and 1.909(6)–2.351(7) Å.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural to 1. As shown in , for 2, the Gd-O and Cu-O bond lengths are in range of 2.294(4)-2.555(4) Å and 1.921(4)-2.338(6) Å. For 3, the Dy-O and Cu-O bond lengths are in range of 2.281(5)-2.547(5) Å and 1.909(6)-2.351(7) Å.

elements.content: The thermogravimertric analysis (TGA) was performed to illustrate the stability of the clusters. As shown in Figure , the TGA curves for 1–3 display an initial weight loss of 10.64% (calcd 10.69%) for 1, 10.81% (calcd 10.54%) for 2, and 10.10% (calcd 10.49%) for 3 between room temperature and 90 °C, suggesting the loss of 15 water molecules of crystallization. The second weight loss of 6.67% (calcd 7.36%) for 1, 7.64% (calcd 7.02%) for 2, and 6.51% (calcd 6.99%) for 3 covering a temperature range from 90 to 200 °C is close to the coordination water molecules. At temperatures higher than 200 °C, 1–3 were rapidly decomposed.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermogravimertric analysis (TGA) was performed to illustrate the stability of the clusters. As shown in Figure , the TGA curves for 1-3 display an initial weight loss of 10.64% (calcd 10.69%) for 1, 10.81% (calcd 10.54%) for 2, and 10.10% (calcd 10.49%) for 3 between room temperature and 90 °C, suggesting the loss of 15 water molecules of crystallization. The second weight loss of 6.67% (calcd 7.36%) for 1, 7.64% (calcd 7.02%) for 2, and 6.51% (calcd 6.99%) for 3 covering a temperature range from 90 to 200 °C is close to the coordination water molecules. At temperatures higher than 200 °C, 1-3 were rapidly decomposed.

elements.content: TGA curves for 1–3 over the temperature 30–800 °C in a nitrogen-gas atmosphere.
elements.clean_text: 3  TGA curves for 1-3 over the temperature 30-800 °C in a nitrogen-gas atmosphere.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 1–3 was measured in the temperature range of 2.0 to 300 K with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. Magnetic studies indicate that the clusters La2Cu8, Gd2Cu8, and Dy 2 Cu8 display diverse magnetic behaviors.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 1-3 was measured in the temperature range of 2.0 to 300 K with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. Magnetic studies indicate that the clusters La2Cu8, Gd2Cu8, and Dy 2 Cu8 display diverse magnetic behaviors.

elements.content: For La2Cu8, the observed χm T value of 2.16 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K is smaller than the expected value of 3.0 cm3 mol–1 K for eight uncoupled/independent Cu2+ ions (g = 2.0) (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value gradually decreases to 0.07 cm3 mol–1 K, suggesting the antiferromagnetic nature. As the La(III) ion is diamagnetic, the over antiferromagnetic behavior of La2Cu8 is contributed from the dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Cu ions.
elements.clean_text: For La2Cu8, the observed χm T value of 2.16 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is smaller than the expected value of 3.0 cm3 mol-1 K for eight uncoupled/independent Cu2+ ions (g = 2.0) (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value gradually decreases to 0.07 cm3 mol-1 K, suggesting the antiferromagnetic nature. As the La(III) ion is diamagnetic, the over antiferromagnetic behavior of La2Cu8 is contributed from the dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Cu ions.

elements.content: Plots of χm T versus T for 1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Plots of χm T versus T for 1.

elements.content: In order to further identify the magnetic exchange interactions between magnetic ions in compounds 1, we simulate the magnetic properties by using three coupling parameters with J 1(Cu1Cu2) = J 1(Cu2Cu3) = J 1(Cu1Cu3) = J 1(Cu1ACu2A) = J 1(Cu2ACu3A) = J 1(Cu1ACu3A), J 2(Cu2Cu4) = J 2(Cu2ACu4A) = J 2(Cu4Cu4A), taking into consideration the couplings propagated by different bridges as shown in Figure . The corresponding Hamiltonians are described as follows: H = − 2 J 1 ( S 1 S 2 + S 2 S 3 + S 1 S 3 + S 1 A S 2 A + S 2 A S 3 A + S 1 A S 3 A ) − 2 J 2 ( S 2 S 4 + S 2 A S 4 A + S 4 S 4 A ) According to the MAGPACK program package, the best simulated values are J 1 = −178.5 cm–1, J 2 = −22.1 cm–1, g = 1.97, and R = 1.13 × 10–3, where R is calculated from ∑[(χm T)obs – (χm T)calcd]2/∑[(χm T)obs]2. The simulated results show that all interactions between Cu2+ ions exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling, which is consistent with the experimental data.
elements.clean_text: In order to further identify the magnetic exchange interactions between magnetic ions in compounds 1, we simulate the magnetic properties by using three coupling parameters with J 1(Cu1Cu2) = J 1(Cu2Cu3) = J 1(Cu1Cu3) = J 1(Cu1ACu2A) = J 1(Cu2ACu3A) = J 1(Cu1ACu3A), J 2(Cu2Cu4) = J 2(Cu2ACu4A) = J 2(Cu4Cu4A), taking into consideration the couplings propagated by different bridges as shown in Figure . The corresponding Hamiltonians are described as follows:  H = - 2   J   1    (   S   1     S   2   +   S   2     S   3   +   S   1     S   3   +   S   1 A     S   2 A   +   S   2 A     S   3 A   +   S   1 A     S   3 A   )  - 2   J   2    (   S   2     S   4   +   S   2 A     S   4 A   +   S   4     S   4 A   )   According to the MAGPACK program package, the best simulated values are J 1 = -178.5 cm-1, J 2 = -22.1 cm-1, g = 1.97, and R = 1.13 × 10-3, where R is calculated from ∑[(χm T)obs - (χm T)calcd]2/∑[(χm T)obs]2. The simulated results show that all interactions between Cu2+ ions exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling, which is consistent with the experimental data.

elements.content: Schematic diagram for magnetic cores of 1.
elements.clean_text: 5  Schematic diagram for magnetic cores of 1.

elements.content: For Gd2Cu8, the χm T values of 18.84 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K is close to the expected value of 18.76 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ ions (S = 7/2, 8S7/2, g = 2) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). The χm T value from 300 K gradually increases to the maximum value of 19.91 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K, indicating the ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu2+ and Gd3+ ions. The temperature dependence of the molar susceptibility is well described by a Curie–Weiss term C = 18.76 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = 0.60 K, consistent with weak ferromagnetic coupling between the Gd3+ and Cu2+ ions. This ferromagnetic interaction is emphasized by the temperature dependence of the difference in χm T between the two compounds, Δχm T = (χm T)(Gd2Cu8) – (χm T)(La 2 Cu8) (). The increase in Δχm T versus T approaching 9 K can be ascribed to Gd–Cu ferromagnetic interactions. Upon further lowering of the temperature, the χm T value decreases to 19.63 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K.
elements.clean_text: For Gd2Cu8, the χm T values of 18.84 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is close to the expected value of 18.76 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ ions (S = 7/2, 8S7/2, g = 2) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). The χm T value from 300 K gradually increases to the maximum value of 19.91 cm3 mol-1 K at 9 K, indicating the ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu2+ and Gd3+ ions. The temperature dependence of the molar susceptibility is well described by a Curie-Weiss term C = 18.76 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = 0.60 K, consistent with weak ferromagnetic coupling between the Gd3+ and Cu2+ ions. This ferromagnetic interaction is emphasized by the temperature dependence of the difference in χm T between the two compounds, Δχm T = (χm T)(Gd2Cu8) - (χm T)(La 2 Cu8) (). The increase in Δχm T versus T approaching 9 K can be ascribed to Gd-Cu ferromagnetic interactions. Upon further lowering of the temperature, the χm T value decreases to 19.63 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K.

elements.content: Plots of χm T versus T and χm –1 versus T for 2; open square corresponds to left axis and filled circle corresponds to right axis.
elements.clean_text: 6  Plots of χm T versus T and χm -1 versus T for 2; open square corresponds to left axis and filled circle corresponds to right axis.

elements.content: Magnetization measurements for Gd2Cu8 in the 2–10 K temperature range were also performed (Figure a). The magnetization displaying a saturation with the applied dc field above 6 T indicates the presence of a negligible magnetic anisotropy. The magnetization M of 16.46 NμB at 2 K is smaller than expected if all spins of the metal ions were ferromagnetically aligned. The observed ground state spin S = 16/2 indicates that the other six Cu ions have a ground state spin S = 0, namely, S = 0 for La2Cu8. These conclusions are supported by ferromagnetic coupling between Gd and Cu ions, but antiferromagnetic coupling between Cu ions dominates the properties of La2Cu8.
elements.clean_text: Magnetization measurements for Gd2Cu8 in the 2-10 K temperature range were also performed (Figure a). The magnetization displaying a saturation with the applied dc field above 6 T indicates the presence of a negligible magnetic anisotropy. The magnetization M of 16.46 NμB at 2 K is smaller than expected if all spins of the metal ions were ferromagnetically aligned. The observed ground state spin S = 16/2 indicates that the other six Cu ions have a ground state spin S = 0, namely, S = 0 for La2Cu8. These conclusions are supported by ferromagnetic coupling between Gd and Cu ions, but antiferromagnetic coupling between Cu ions dominates the properties of La2Cu8.

elements.content: Plots of field-dependent magnetization at indicated temperatures for 2 (a) and ΔS m calculated by using the magnetization data of 2 at various fields and temperatures (b).
elements.clean_text: 7  Plots of field-dependent magnetization at indicated temperatures for 2 (a) and ΔS m calculated by using the magnetization data of 2 at various fields and temperatures (b).

elements.content: As a key parameter in evaluating the MCE, magnetic entropy change ΔS m can be calculated from the Maxwell relation Δ S m(T) = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T] H dH. As shown in Figure b, the value of ΔS m is 12.8 J kg–1 K–1 at 3 K for ΔH = 7 T. The experimental value is smaller than the theoretical value of 31.47 J kg–1 K–1 calculated for two uncorrelated Gd3+ (S Gd = 7/2) and eight uncorrelated Cu2+ (S Cu = 1/2) ions using the equation −ΔS m = nR ln(2s + 1) = 2R ln(8) + 8R ln(2). The reason may be attributed to the presence of intracluster antiferromagnetic interactions and the crystal field effect.
elements.clean_text: As a key parameter in evaluating the MCE, magnetic entropy change ΔS m can be calculated from the Maxwell relation Δ S  m(T) = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T] H  dH. As shown in Figure b, the value of ΔS m is 12.8 J kg-1 K-1 at 3 K for ΔH = 7 T. The experimental value is smaller than the theoretical value of 31.47 J kg-1 K-1 calculated for two uncorrelated Gd3+ (S Gd = 7/2) and eight uncorrelated Cu2+ (S Cu = 1/2) ions using the equation -ΔS m = nR ln(2s + 1) = 2R ln(8) + 8R ln(2). The reason may be attributed to the presence of intracluster antiferromagnetic interactions and the crystal field effect.

elements.content: For Dy2Cu8, the χm T values of 30.95 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K correspond to the expected value of 31.34 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (S = 5/2, 6H15/2, g = 4/3) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 12 K, the χm T values gradually decreases to 28.26 cm3 mol–1 K. With decreasing temperature, the χm T value increases with a little peak of 28.64 cm3 mol–1 K at 5 K, and then decreases to 28.29 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The decrease in χm T with decreasing temperature may be ascribed to the thermal depopulation of excited stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions.

Upon cooling from 300 to 12 K, the χm T values gradually decreases to 28.26 cm3 mol-1 K. With decreasing temperature, the χm T value increases with a little peak of 28.64 cm3 mol-1 K at 5 K, and then decreases to 28.29 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The decrease in χm T with decreasing temperature may be ascribed to the thermal depopulation of excited stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions.

elements.content: The field dependence of magnetization of Dy2Cu8 is shown in . The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly below 1.0 T, and then slowly and linearly increases to 14.62 NμB at 7 T, suggesting the ferromagnetic interaction between Dy and Cu ions and other six Cu ions have a S = 0 ground state spin. The nonsuperposition M versus H/T plots () indicates the presence of a significant anisotropy.
elements.clean_text: The field dependence of magnetization of Dy2Cu8 is shown in . The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly below 1.0 T, and then slowly and linearly increases to 14.62 NμB at 7 T, suggesting the ferromagnetic interaction between Dy and Cu ions and other six Cu ions have a S = 0 ground state spin. The nonsuperposition M versus H/T plots () indicates the presence of a significant anisotropy.

elements.content: Ac susceptibility measurements for Dy2Cu8 was also characterized under H dc = 0 Oe and H ac = 3 Oe at the indicated frequencies (Figure ). The Dy2Cu8 displays a frequency dependent out-of-phase signal, indicating the slow magnetization relaxation. However, owing to the absence of frequency-dependent peaks in ac susceptibility signals, the energy barrier and characteristic relation time cannot be obtained by fitting the peak temperatures to an Arrhenius–type expression. Alternatively, assuming that there is only one characteristic relaxation process, the energy barrier and τ0 values can be obtained from fitting the frequency-dependent ac susceptibility data by using Debye model based on the relationship ln(χ″/χ′) = ln(ωτ0) + E a/K B T, which has been applied in reported clusters. As shown in , the extracted E a = 0.82 K, τ0 = 8.02 × 10–6 s, which is consistent with the expected numbers (τ0 = 10–6–10–11 s) for SMMs.
elements.clean_text: Ac susceptibility measurements for Dy2Cu8 was also characterized under H dc = 0 Oe and H ac = 3 Oe at the indicated frequencies (Figure ). The Dy2Cu8 displays a frequency dependent out-of-phase signal, indicating the slow magnetization relaxation. However, owing to the absence of frequency-dependent peaks in ac susceptibility signals, the energy barrier and characteristic relation time cannot be obtained by fitting the peak temperatures to an Arrhenius-type expression. Alternatively, assuming that there is only one characteristic relaxation process, the energy barrier and τ0 values can be obtained from fitting the frequency-dependent ac susceptibility data by using Debye model based on the relationship ln(χ"/χ') = ln(ωτ0) + E a/K B T, which has been applied in reported clusters. As shown in , the extracted E a = 0.82 K, τ0 = 8.02 × 10-6 s, which is consistent with the expected numbers (τ0 = 10-6-10-11 s) for SMMs.

elements.content: Plots of temperature dependence of the in-phase (a) and out-of-phase (b) ac susceptibilities at the indicated frequencies for 3.
elements.clean_text: 9  Plots of temperature dependence of the in-phase (a) and out-of-phase (b) ac susceptibilities at the indicated frequencies for 3.

elements.content: In order to suppress the possible tunneling effect, we carried out ac measurements by applying a 2 kOe dc field at various frequencies from 1 to 1500 Hz. As shown in , the frequency dependence of the in-phase and out-of phase ac susceptibility was observed.
elements.clean_text: In order to suppress the possible tunneling effect, we carried out ac measurements by applying a 2 kOe dc field at various frequencies from 1 to 1500 Hz. As shown in , the frequency dependence of the in-phase and out-of phase ac susceptibility was observed.

elements.content: It is interesting that a family of isometallic Ln2Cu8 compounds with a sandwiched structure have been reported by Borta et al, based on 2-hydroxypyridine. Although possessing a distinct crystal structure, these two series of isometallic Ln2Cu8 compounds display similar magnetic properties. Both the present La2Cu8 and the sandwiched Y2Cu8 show an overall antiferromagnetic behavior dominated by an antiferromagnetic interaction between the copper ions, and both the Dy2Cu8 exhibit slow magnetic relaxation due to the anisotropy of Dy sites. Interestingly, owing to the larger Cu–Gd interaction and the anisotropy of the Cu sites, the sandwiched Gd2Cu8 displayed single-molecule magnet (SMM) behavior, but no SMM behavior was found in our present Gd2Cu8.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting that a family of isometallic Ln2Cu8 compounds with a sandwiched structure have been reported by Borta et al, based on 2-hydroxypyridine. Although possessing a distinct crystal structure, these two series of isometallic Ln2Cu8 compounds display similar magnetic properties. Both the present La2Cu8 and the sandwiched Y2Cu8 show an overall antiferromagnetic behavior dominated by an antiferromagnetic interaction between the copper ions, and both the Dy2Cu8 exhibit slow magnetic relaxation due to the anisotropy of Dy sites. Interestingly, owing to the larger Cu-Gd interaction and the anisotropy of the Cu sites, the sandwiched Gd2Cu8 displayed single-molecule magnet (SMM) behavior, but no SMM behavior was found in our present Gd2Cu8.

elements.content: In summary, three decanuclear 3d–4f clusters based on alkylsulfonate group ligand were synthesized. Magnetic studies indicate that the La2Cu8 cluster exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior, while the Gd2Cu8 displays ferromagnetic behavior and large magnetocaloric effect at low temperature, which have potential application in developing magnetic cooling technology in the ultralow temperature range. Replacement of Gd3+ ions with anisotropic Dy3+ ions caused the Dy2Cu8 to show slow magnetic relaxation. This work would be helpful for the rational design and assembly of 3d–4f based molecular magnets.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, three decanuclear 3d-4f clusters based on alkylsulfonate group ligand were synthesized. Magnetic studies indicate that the La2Cu8 cluster exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior, while the Gd2Cu8 displays ferromagnetic behavior and large magnetocaloric effect at low temperature, which have potential application in developing magnetic cooling technology in the ultralow temperature range. Replacement of Gd3+ ions with anisotropic Dy3+ ions caused the Dy2Cu8 to show slow magnetic relaxation. This work would be helpful for the rational design and assembly of 3d-4f based molecular magnets.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

cln_elements.content:
Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242g, 1.0 mmol), La(ClO4)3 (2 mL, aq. 1.0 M), and 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)-methylamino]-2-hydroxypropanesulfonic acid (0.130g, 0.5 mmol) were added to deionized water (10 mL). The resulting solution was heated to reflux, and its pH was adjusted to about 7 with the addition of NaOH (aq. 1.0 M). The mixture was refluxed for 1 h and then filtrated. Evaporation of the deep blue solution under ambient conditions afforded 110 mg of blue crystals 1 over one month (yield 34.3% based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8La2N4O65S4 (%) Anal. (FW = 2524.474): C, 13.32%; H, 4.23%; N, 2.22%; Found: C, 13.77%; H, 4.47%; N, 2.20%.

[Gd<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>8</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-OH)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-OH)<sub>2</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>­(HTMHSA)<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>10</sub>]­·15H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

This compound was prepared using Gd(ClO4)3 in place of La(ClO4)3 under otherwise identical conditions as described above which afforded 132 mg of blue sheetlike crystals of 2 (Yield: 40.0%, based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8Gd2N4O65S4 Anal. (FW = 2561.163): C, 13.13%; H, 4.17%; N, 2.19%; Found: C, 13.16%; H, 4.33%; N, 2.12%.

This compound was prepared using Dy(ClO4)3 in place of La(ClO4)3 under otherwise identical conditions as described above which afforded 113 mg of blue sheetlike crystals of 3 (yield: 35.1%, based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8Dy2N4O65S4 Anal. (FW = 2571.663): C, 13.08%; H, 4.15%; N, 2.18%; Found: C, 13.31%; H, 4.26%; N, 2.19%.

Synthesis

[La2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]⋅15H2O (1)

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.242g, 1.0 mmol), La(ClO4)3 (2 mL, aq. 1.0 M), and 3-[N-tris(hydroxymethyl)-methylamino]-2-hydroxypropanesulfonic acid (0.130g, 0.5 mmol) were added to deionized water (10 mL). The resulting solution was heated to reflux, and its pH was adjusted to about 7 with the addition of NaOH (aq. 1.0 M). The mixture was refluxed for 1 h and then filtrated. Evaporation of the deep blue solution under ambient conditions afforded 110 mg of blue crystals 1 over one month (yield 34.3% based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8La2N4O65S4 (%) Anal. (FW = 2524.474): C, 13.32%; H, 4.23%; N, 2.22%; Found: C, 13.77%; H, 4.47%; N, 2.20%.

[Gd2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]⋅15H2O (2)

This compound was prepared using Gd(ClO4)3 in place of La(ClO4)3 under otherwise identical conditions as described above which afforded 132 mg of blue sheetlike crystals of 2 (Yield: 40.0%, based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8Gd2N4O65S4 Anal. (FW = 2561.163): C, 13.13%; H, 4.17%; N, 2.19%; Found: C, 13.16%; H, 4.33%; N, 2.12%.

[Dy2Cu8(μ2-OH)2(μ3-OH)2(ClO4)2(HTMHSA)4(H2O)10]⋅15H2O (3)

This compound was prepared using Dy(ClO4)3 in place of La(ClO4)3 under otherwise identical conditions as described above which afforded 113 mg of blue sheetlike crystals of 3 (yield: 35.1%, based on H5TMHSA). C28H106Cl2Cu8Dy2N4O65S4 Anal. (FW = 2571.663): C, 13.08%; H, 4.15%; N, 2.18%; Found: C, 13.31%; H, 4.26%; N, 2.19%.

cln_elements.content:
The thermogravimertric analysis (TGA) was performed to illustrate the stability of the clusters. As shown in Figure , the TGA curves for 1–3 display an initial weight loss of 10.64% (calcd 10.69%) for 1, 10.81% (calcd 10.54%) for 2, and 10.10% (calcd 10.49%) for 3 between room temperature and 90 °C, suggesting the loss of 15 water molecules of crystallization. The second weight loss of 6.67% (calcd 7.36%) for 1, 7.64% (calcd 7.02%) for 2, and 6.51% (calcd 6.99%) for 3 covering a temperature range from 90 to 200 °C is close to the coordination water molecules. At temperatures higher than 200 °C, 1–3 were rapidly decomposed.

For La2Cu8, the observed χm T value of 2.16 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K is smaller than the expected value of 3.0 cm3 mol–1 K for eight uncoupled/independent Cu2+ ions (g = 2.0) (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value gradually decreases to 0.07 cm3 mol–1 K, suggesting the antiferromagnetic nature. As the La(III) ion is diamagnetic, the over antiferromagnetic behavior of La2Cu8 is contributed from the dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Cu ions.

For Gd2Cu8, the χm T values of 18.84 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K is close to the expected value of 18.76 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ ions (S = 7/2, 8S7/2, g = 2) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). The χm T value from 300 K gradually increases to the maximum value of 19.91 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K, indicating the ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu2+ and Gd3+ ions. The temperature dependence of the molar susceptibility is well described by a Curie–Weiss term C = 18.76 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = 0.60 K, consistent with weak ferromagnetic coupling between the Gd3+ and Cu2+ ions. This ferromagnetic interaction is emphasized by the temperature dependence of the difference in χm T between the two compounds, Δχm T = (χm T)(Gd2Cu8) – (χm T)(La 2 Cu8) (). The increase in Δχm T versus T approaching 9 K can be ascribed to Gd–Cu ferromagnetic interactions. Upon further lowering of the temperature, the χm T value decreases to 19.63 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K.

For Dy2Cu8, the χm T values of 30.95 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K correspond to the expected value of 31.34 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (S = 5/2, 6H15/2, g = 4/3) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 12 K, the χm T values gradually decreases to 28.26 cm3 mol–1 K. With decreasing temperature, the χm T value increases with a little peak of 28.64 cm3 mol–1 K at 5 K, and then decreases to 28.29 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The decrease in χm T with decreasing temperature may be ascribed to the thermal depopulation of excited stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions.

The field dependence of magnetization of Dy2Cu8 is shown in . The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly below 1.0 T, and then slowly and linearly increases to 14.62 NμB at 7 T, suggesting the ferromagnetic interaction between Dy and Cu ions and other six Cu ions have a S = 0 ground state spin. The nonsuperposition M versus H/T plots () indicates the presence of a significant anisotropy.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermogravimertric analysis (TGA) was performed to illustrate the stability of the clusters. As shown in Figure , the TGA curves for 1-3 display an initial weight loss of 10.64% (calcd 10.69%) for 1, 10.81% (calcd 10.54%) for 2, and 10.10% (calcd 10.49%) for 3 between room temperature and 90 °C, suggesting the loss of 15 water molecules of crystallization. The second weight loss of 6.67% (calcd 7.36%) for 1, 7.64% (calcd 7.02%) for 2, and 6.51% (calcd 6.99%) for 3 covering a temperature range from 90 to 200 °C is close to the coordination water molecules. At temperatures higher than 200 °C, 1-3 were rapidly decomposed.

For La2Cu8, the observed χm T value of 2.16 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is smaller than the expected value of 3.0 cm3 mol-1 K for eight uncoupled/independent Cu2+ ions (g = 2.0) (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value gradually decreases to 0.07 cm3 mol-1 K, suggesting the antiferromagnetic nature. As the La(III) ion is diamagnetic, the over antiferromagnetic behavior of La2Cu8 is contributed from the dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Cu ions.

For Gd2Cu8, the χm T values of 18.84 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is close to the expected value of 18.76 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ ions (S = 7/2, 8S7/2, g = 2) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). The χm T value from 300 K gradually increases to the maximum value of 19.91 cm3 mol-1 K at 9 K, indicating the ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu2+ and Gd3+ ions. The temperature dependence of the molar susceptibility is well described by a Curie-Weiss term C = 18.76 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = 0.60 K, consistent with weak ferromagnetic coupling between the Gd3+ and Cu2+ ions. This ferromagnetic interaction is emphasized by the temperature dependence of the difference in χm T between the two compounds, Δχm T = (χm T)(Gd2Cu8) - (χm T)(La 2 Cu8) (). The increase in Δχm T versus T approaching 9 K can be ascribed to Gd-Cu ferromagnetic interactions. Upon further lowering of the temperature, the χm T value decreases to 19.63 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K.

For Dy2Cu8, the χm T values of 30.95 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K correspond to the expected value of 31.34 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (S = 5/2, 6H15/2, g = 4/3) and eight Cu2+ ions (Figure ). Upon cooling from 300 to 12 K, the χm T values gradually decreases to 28.26 cm3 mol-1 K. With decreasing temperature, the χm T value increases with a little peak of 28.64 cm3 mol-1 K at 5 K, and then decreases to 28.29 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The decrease in χm T with decreasing temperature may be ascribed to the thermal depopulation of excited stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ions.

The field dependence of magnetization of Dy2Cu8 is shown in . The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly below 1.0 T, and then slowly and linearly increases to 14.62 NμB at 7 T, suggesting the ferromagnetic interaction between Dy and Cu ions and other six Cu ions have a S = 0 ground state spin. The nonsuperposition M versus H/T plots () indicates the presence of a significant anisotropy.
